Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Topological mechanism of DNA unlinking by the XerCD-FtsK system
Award.AbstractNarration:
DNA topology is the study of knotting, linking and supercoiling of circular DNA molecules. The bacterial chromosome is circular and replication invariably results in the formation of interlinked daughter chromosomes. Error-free unlinking is required to ensure proper segregation at cell division and stable plasmid inheritance. Type II topoisomerases unlink replication links. In Escherichia coli, in the absence of topo IV (a type II topoisomerase credited with chromosome unlinking), the site-specific recombination system XerCD mediates sister chromosome unlinking. This reaction is activated at the division septum by a powerful translocase FtsK, which coordinates the last stages of chromosome segregation. The mechanism by which the XerCD-FtsK complex simplifies the topology of DNA remains unclear. The main objective of the proposed studies is to characterize the topological mechanism of DNA unlinking by the XerCD-FtsK system using knot theory, low-dimensional topology, and computer simulations. There is evidence that after being activated by FtsK, the enzymes XerCD unlink DNA in a stepwise manner. The tangle method will be used to find possible topological pathways of DNA unknotting and unlinking by site-specific recombination on small substrates. A computer model of DNA recombination will be developed, adapted to the Xer-FtsK system, and combined with the analytical results to analyze experimental data obtained from the Sherratt lab. The research is highly interdisciplinary and involves close collaboration with groups in Japan, Canada and the UK. Such collaborations will facilitate state-of-the-art student cross-training. Basic information about DNA topology will be disseminated to the general public, including elementary school children and visitors to the California Academy of Sciences.


DNA replication is the basis for biological inheritance. In bacteria, reproduction starts with replication of the chromosome into two identical daughter molecules, followed by segregation of the newly replicated chromosomes and division of the parent cell into two daughter cells. In circular chromosomes, problems of entanglement during DNA linking complicate the process of chromosome segregation. In Escherichia coli, DNA unlinking is typically mediated by the enzyme topoIV, which is an important drug target for quinolone antimicrobial agents. Understanding DNA unlinking by Xer recombination, in addition to providing a more complete picture of the chromosome segregation process, is highly relevant for drug design. Mathematical and computational tools are very useful for studying the action of enzymes that change the topology of DNA. In this project such tools will be used to characterize all unlinking pathways and to reveal the mechanism of unlinking by Xer. The educational goal is to develop new and effective ways to disseminate knowledge related to DNA topology and its biological significance, as well as to increase public awareness of the critical role of mathematics in understanding biological processes. The proposed plans include the creation of Math Circles for elementary school children in San Francisco and the development of a series of educational materials for public consumption in collaboration with the California Academy of Sciences. This will culminate in the production of an exhibit on DNA topology for the general public in the California Academy of Sciences Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to characterize the topological mechanism of DNA topology simplification by a site-specific recombination system from Escherichia coli using tools from knot theory, low-dimensional topology and computer simulations and visualizations. The project was highly interdisciplinary and involved international collaborations with research groups in Japan, Canada, and the UK.                                                     

 

Replication of circular chromosomes yields two copies of the parental DNA molecule. Because DNA is a double helix, the two newly replicated chromosomes are topologically linked. In E. coli, the enzyme topo IV unlinks replication links prior to cell division. It was reported that in the absence of topo IV replication links can be unlinked by site-specific recombination. Site-specific recombination acts by local reconnection between two DNA sites. Mathematical links are used to model DNA knots and links, and local reconnection is modelled as a coherent band surgery. The complexity of a link can be quantified by computing its minimal crossing number. This project used the tangle method and other tools from knot theory and low-dimensional topology to identify possible topological pathways of DNA unknotting and unlinking by reconnection on small knots and links. The length of any shortest pathway of unlinking a DNA replication link was determined analytically. We showed that there is a unique minimal pathway if we assume that the complexity of the substrate is strictly reduced at every step of the process (pathway along the diagonal in Figure 1). We relaxed this assumption by allowing the complexity to go down or remain fixed after each reconnection event. We then determined analytically that there are exactly nine possible pathways of DNA unlinking starting with a 6-crossing replication link (Figure 1). We also characterized the mechanisms of enzymatic action corresponding to several steps along the pathways (Figure 2).

 

In the second part of the project, a software suite to simulate local reconnection was developed. Knots and links were modeled as self-avoiding polygons in the simple cubic lattice and a reconnection site was defined by a pair of parallel edges, distance 1 apart, and with possible arc length constraints (Figure 3). In the study of topology simplification after replication, reconnection was modelled as coherent band surgery where the substrates are links with one site in each component, or knots with two sites in a particular orientation. A Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm with Multiple Markov Chain sampling was used to model reconnection on 491 different knots and links and to distinguish between pathways involving a total of 881 topologies. From the numerical study we concluded that the minimal pathway of unlinking replication links found under the strict reduction in complexity assumption is the most probable (Figure 4). These results point to a universal process of topology simplification by local reconnection with applications in fluid dynamics and other fields.  

 

From this project stemmed a few more theoretical investigations. The computational study required an unambiguous nomenclature for knots and links (Figure 5). The nomenclature choice was made based on our conjecture that chiral knots can be unambiguously distinguished from their mirror images by the sign of their overall writhe. The study for 2-component links was more involved since some link types admit up to 16 different symmetry classes. Other ramifications included research into minimal step number configurations for lattice knots and links in open space and in confinement, and an investigation of knots represented as grid diagrams. Finally, we conducted studies of tangles embedded in tetrahedra to facilitate the study of topological mechanism of recombination.

 

The research findings have contributed new mathematical and computational tools to the study of site-specific recombination, including novel applications of methods from knot theory and low dimensional topology, and a sophisticated software suite to model local reconnection. Furthermore the results and methods are universally applicable to reconnection in other contexts, e.g. the study of unlinking of knotted and linked vortices in fluids.

 

A variety of student trainees from both the PI’s lab and the collaborators’ labs were exposed to interdisciplinary training and had access to  international research collaborations. This project also followed an ambitious educational program that has established the PI as a leader in DNA topology dissemination. The PI established a San Francisco Math Circles program for elementary school children that focused on introducing mathematics through geometrical and topological concepts (Figure 6). Several modules were centered around applications to DNA topology. We have actively worked on disseminating the tools and results of our research to the general public. For example, the PI has collaborated with the National Math Festival (2015 and 2017) and with the Fleet Science Center in San Diego (2018), has been featured in two Numberphile.com videos and has given a variety of public lectures and interviews nationally and internationally. The two key paper outcomes from this project had press releases and received media attention.
